data.title: Who should the girls marry? (V.2)
data.statement:
A group of elementary school girls evaluates which boy in school each girl should eventually marry.

They do this by thinking about what their married names would be (the girl's first name plus the boy's last name). 

They consider that the best last name is one that has the most letters that are in the girl's first name.

For example, the [[commonLetterCount]] for {{Larrisa}} and Jack {{Riraldi}} is 5, namely {{R}}, {{R}}, {{I}}, {{A}}, {{L}}
Because:
{{R}} counts twice because it is in Larrisa (2x) and Riraldi (2x)
{{I}} only counts once because it is in Larrisa (1x) and Riraldi (2x) 
{{A}} only counts once because it is in Larrisa (2x) and Riraldi (1x)
{{L}} only counts once because it is in Larrisa (1x) and Riraldi (1x)

If that is more than the [[commonLetterCount]] for any other boy in school, then Larrisa should marry him.

testCases.title: Test 1
testCases.testIn:
3
Larrisa
Jolie
Daphne
4
Jack Riraldi
Paul Ayala
Frederic Hamed
Amos Otieno
testCases.testOut:
Larrisa marries Jack Riraldi
Jolie marries Amos Otieno
Daphne marries Frederic Hamed

data.constraints:
For each girl, there is always one clear winner (no ties).

[[boyFullName]] always consists of two words.
data.stubGenerator:
read numGirls:int
loop numGirls read girlFirstName:string(20)
read numBoys:int
loop numBoys read boyFullName:string(40)
write who marries who
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer, number of girls [[numGirls]]
<<Next [[numGirls]] Lines:>> A string, first name of each girl [[girlFirstName]]
<<Next Line:>> An integer, number of boys in school [[numBoys]]
<<Next [[numBoys]] Lines:>> A string, full name (first and last) of each boy [[boyFullName]]

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

A group of elementary school girls evaluates which boy in school each girl should eventually marry.

They do this by thinking about what their married names would be (the girl's first name plus the boy's last name).

They consider that the best last name is one that has the most letters that are in the girl's first name.

For example, the commonLetterCount for Larrisa and Jack Riraldi is 5, namely R, R, I, A, L
Because:
R counts twice because it is in Larrisa (2x) and Riraldi (2x)
I only counts once because it is in Larrisa (1x) and Riraldi (2x)
A only counts once because it is in Larrisa (2x) and Riraldi (1x)
L only counts once because it is in Larrisa (1x) and Riraldi (1x)

If that is more than the commonLetterCount for any other boy in school, then Larrisa should marry him.
Input
Line 1: An integer, number of girls numGirls
Next numGirls Lines: A string, first name of each girl girlFirstName
Next Line: An integer, number of boys in school numBoys
Next numBoys Lines: A string, full name (first and last) of each boy boyFullName
Output
numGirls Lines: girlFirstName marries boyFullName
Constraints
For each girl, there is always one clear winner (no ties).

boyFullName always consists of two words.
Example
Input
3
Larrisa
Jolie
Daphne
4
Jack Riraldi
Paul Ayala
Frederic Hamed
Amos Otieno
Output
Larrisa marries Jack Riraldi
Jolie marries Amos Otieno
Daphne marries Frederic Hamed
